title: Classic French Onion Soup
description: A rich, hearty soup with caramelized onions, beef broth, and melted Gruyère cheese on toasted bread. This recipe demonstrates multiple cooking techniques including knife skills, sautéing, simmering, and finishing.

steps.instruction_text: Peel the onions and slice them thinly into half-moon shapes, about 1/4 inch thick. You should have approximately 6 cups of sliced onions.
Mince the garlic cloves finely and set aside. Chop the fresh thyme leaves.
In a large heavy-bottomed pot, melt the butter over medium heat. Add the sliced onions and toss to coat them evenly with the butter.
Sauté the onions for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they begin to soften and turn translucent.
Reduce the heat to medium-low and continue to caramelize the onions for 30-40 minutes, stirring every 5 minutes. The onions should turn a deep golden brown color and become very sweet.
Add the minced garlic and chopped thyme to the caramelized onions. Stir and cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Deglaze the pot by adding the white wine, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom with a wooden spoon.
Pour in the beef broth and add the bay leaves. Bring the mixture to a boil over high heat.
Once boiling, reduce the heat to low and simmer the soup for 20-25 minutes to allow the flavors to meld together.
While the soup simmers, slice the baguette into 1-inch thick rounds. Toast the bread slices under the broiler until golden brown on both sides.
Grate the Gruyère cheese and set aside.
Preheat your oven's broiler to high. Ladle the hot soup into oven-safe bowls, filling them about 3/4 full.
Place a toasted bread slice on top of each bowl of soup. Generously top the bread with the grated Gruyère cheese.
Broil the soup bowls for 3-4 minutes until the cheese is melted, bubbly, and golden brown on top.
Remove from the oven and let rest for 2 minutes before serving. Garnish with fresh thyme leaves if desired.
